_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. Facility Policy.



If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Fillmore County Emergency Management, and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the public and the environment.



2. Facility Information.



The primary activity at the facility is the production of anhydrous ammonia as an agricultural product. The ammonia production process uses natural gas and ambient air as production inputs. The natural gas and ambient air react to produce anhydrous ammonia.



3. Five-Year Accident History.



No accidents have occurred within the most recent five-year history.



4. Emergency Response.



The emergency response program established by Fortigen Geneva does not allow for personnel to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances. Fortigen Geneva has identified resources mitigate, control, and dispose of a release. The local emergency response agency (Fillmore County Emergency Management) will be relied upon to inform the public about the release. Fortigen Geneva has developed an Emergency Action Plan outlining actions taken in the event of an accidental release of regulated substances as well as in the event of natural disasters. The Emergency Action Plan is provided below for reference.



5. Accidental Release Prevention Program.



Fortigen Geneva has implemented environmental, emergency, and safety programs. Equipment maintenance checks are completed that assist in the ability for Fortigen Geneva staff to respond to emergencies. Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasure (SPCC) and Storm Water Pollution Prevention (SWPP) plans have been prepared and implemented. Updates will be completed as needed to ensure compliance and effectiveness. Fortigen Geneva has developed a Prevention Program in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68 for a Program Level 3 facility. 



The facility conducts weekly and monthly training as p

art of normal activities. Training consists of regulated safety requirements. A Process Safety Management (PSM) program has been implemented. Anhydrous ammonia is a PSD-applicable chemical on site. Safety inspections are completed regularly with in-house and outside expertise as necessary. Periodic reviews are completed on plans and procedures, with scheduling for additional training as part of the review process. 



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety.



Routine evaluations are completed to assess equipment conditions at the facility. Fortigen Geneva has a metal integrity written plan to confirm chemical storage tanks are in proper working condition. 





EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN



1. Policy Statement. 



Fortigen Geneva believes that is employees are its most important asset, and that their safety and health are among its greatest responsibilities. This Emergency Action Plan was created in compliance with OSHA standard, Title 29 CFR 1910.38 (a) and posted for all Fortigen Geneva employees.



2. Purpose.



This Emergency Action Plan is intended to ensure the proper response to foreseeable emergencies and where necessary, ensure the orderly evacuation of employees from work locations to a safe area away from conditions that could be immediately dangerous to life and health.



3. Responsibility and Authority.



A Program Coordinator is assigned by the Chief Executive Officer to oversee:

(a) the development, implementation, and ongoing improvement of the Emergency Action Plan,

(b) Development and posting of the Emergency Action Plan posters and site exit diagram,

(c) All emergency equipment is inspected at various intervals to ensure proper operation of all emergency equipment, and

(d) Periodic drills of the emergency action plan.



The following procedures will be followed by all visitors/contractors entering the facility:



(a) Monday through Friday between 7 a.m. and 5 p.m. (Normal office hours) - all visitors and contractors will sign-in and out at th

e administrative office. In the event work schedule starts or continues past normal offices hours, sign-in and out will be completed at the control room.

(b) Monday through Friday between 5 p.m. and 7 a.m. - all visitors and contractors will sign-in and out at the control room.

(c) Saturday and Sunday - all visitors and contractors will sign-in and out at the control room.

(d) Contractors on site are required to supply company name and total contractor personnel on site.

(e) Contractors, not accompanied by Fortigen Geneva personnel, may be provided a radio to communicate with Fortigen Geneva personnel. This will be determined during project planning, pre-job briefing, or heightened security risk.

(f) If an evacuation is required: 

   (i)A pre-assigned Control room operator will collect the sign-in ledger located in the Control Room. 

   (ii) A pre-assigned Fortigen Geneva employee in the Administrative Office will collect the sign-in ledger located in the Administrative Office.

   (iii) A role call will occur. 

   (iv) In the event a person is presumed to be missing, attempts will be made through radio communication. If attempts to communicate with missing people are unsuccessful, Fortigen Geneva personnel will wait for emergency services to arrive before re-entering the facility.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE INFORMATION



1. Facility Information



Fortigen Geneva

2240 R Street

Geneva, Nebraska 68361



County: Fillmore County



Fortigen Geneva Phone Number for Emergency Response Personnel: (402) 366-1608



Risk Management Plan Manager: Amber Hoban



Fire protection equipment contractor: Ahearn



Fire protection equipment contractor phone number: (402) 894-1045 (Ahearn in Omaha)



2. Spill Response Notifications



Nebraska Department of Environmental Quality (NDEQ)

Monday through Friday (8 a.m. through 5 p.m.), non-holidays

Phone number: 402-471-2186





Nebraska State Patrol Dispatch

After hours, Weekends, and Holidays

Phone number: 402-471-4545

Notifications to the NDEQ or Nebraska State Patrol Dispatch must be made if any of the following occur:

(a) Acute emergencies, such as spills or releases of petroleum products or hazardous substances.

(b) Any oil release that impacts or threatens waters of the state or threatens the public health.

(c) Any release of oil upon the surface of the land in a quantity that exceeds 25 gallons. This notification must be made immediately (verbal) and a written notification must be made within 15 days of discharge or as requested by the NDEQ.



Fortigen Geneva will refer to Nebraska Title 126 for additional requirements pertaining to notification of spills.





National Response Center

(24-hour phone number) 1-800-424-8802



Notifications to the National Response Center must be made immediately for each instance of a discharge reaching navigable waters.





EPA Region 7 Hotline

(24-hour phone number) 1-913-281-0991



Immediately call the EPA Region 7 Hotline for each instance of a discharge reaching navigable waters.





EPA Region 7 Regional Administrator

Monday through Friday (8 a.m. through 4:30 p.m.)

913-551-7003



A single discharge of 1,000 gallons or more, or two or more discharges of 42 gallons or more over a 12-month period requires written notification to the EPA Region 7 Regional Administrator with 60 days of discharge.
